questions.text: First disease which had established etiology of a micro-organism in 1687 is
questions.solution:
• Scabies was identified in 1687 by Giovanni Cosimo Bonomo and Diacinto Cestoni as being caused by a microscopic mite, Sarcoptes scabiei, marking it as the first disease with an established microbial cause.
  • This discovery was critical in advancing early parasitology and infectious disease understanding, as it was among the first to establish that microscopic organisms could cause visible disease symptoms.
  • Bonomo's findings contributed to early epidemiology, emphasizing the importance of microscopic pathogens and shaping the early concepts of germ theory, later developed by scientists like Pasteur and Koch.

Why Not Others:

  • A. Malaria: The Plasmodium parasite was only identified in 1880 by Alphonse Laveran.
  • B. Smallpox: Caused by the variola virus, its viral nature was not understood until much later with advances in virology.
  • C. Dracunculiasis: Dracunculus medinensis was recognized as the cause of dracunculiasis, but this was not identified in 1687.

Key Takeaway: Scabies is notable as the first documented case of a disease caused by a microscopic organism, setting the foundation for modern microbiology and understanding of parasitic and infectious diseases.

questions.text: Siphon tube is absent in larvae of the following
questions.solution:
• Anopheles larvae lack a siphon tube, unlike Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia larvae, which use siphon tubes to access oxygen at or below the water's surface.
  • They rest parallel to the water surface and obtain oxygen through spiracles located on the upper abdominal segments, which align them horizontally.
  • This horizontal position serves as camouflage, reducing visibility to predators, while the absence of a siphon tube enables more efficient oxygen intake without relying on an extended tube.
  • Anopheles larvae's behavior of floating parallel to the water surface and periodic diving helps them adapt to different aquatic environments and enhances survival rates.
  • Comparison of the characteristics of mosquito larvae from different genera:

Why Not Others:

  • Culex: Has a long siphon tube, allowing it to stay submerged at an angle for efficient gas exchange.
  • Aedes: Also uses a siphon tube for breathing, positioning itself at an angle.
  • Mansonia: Has a specialized siphon tube that pierces submerged vegetation to obtain oxygen, allowing it to remain hidden.

Key Takeaway: Anopheles larvae's lack of a siphon tube enables them to float horizontally at the water's surface and breathe through spiracles, aiding camouflage and predator avoidance-key survival adaptations.

questions.text: Mosquitoes that breed in dirty water collection are:
questions.solution:
• Culex mosquitoes are well-suited to polluted, stagnant water, thriving in places like sewage, drains, and puddles with high organic content.
  • They are commonly found in urban and suburban areas where water quality is poor and stagnant sources are prevalent.
  • Culex mosquitoes are significant vectors for diseases such as West Nile virus, lymphatic filariasis, and Japanese encephalitis, often targeting human and bird hosts.
  • Their adaptability to polluted environments gives them a year-round breeding advantage, especially in densely populated areas.
  • Breeding places for different genera of mosquitoes:

Why Not Others:

  • A. Anopheles: Prefers clean, slow-moving or stagnant water, such as ponds and streams.
  • C. Aedes: Breeds in clean, stagnant water in small containers like buckets, tires, and flower pots.
  • D. Mansonia: Uses vegetated water sources and relies on aquatic plants for oxygen, allowing them to avoid surface breathing.

Key Takeaway:
Culex mosquitoes, adapted to dirty and polluted water, are prominent urban vectors, breeding in environments unsuitable for other mosquito species and transmitting diseases like West Nile virus and lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: Normal life span of mosquitoes is:
questions.solution:
• The average life span of mosquitoes is 8-34 days, with females generally living longer than males to complete reproductive cycles.
  • Environmental conditions like temperature, humidity, and food availability significantly impact lifespan. In warmer climates, the life cycle accelerates, potentially shortening their life span.
  • Males typically live 5-7 days as they only need to mate, while females survive longer as they require blood meals to lay eggs.

Life Cycle Stages of Mosquitoes:

  1. Egg Stage:
    • Duration: 2-3 days, depending on temperature.
    • Anopheles eggs float on water surfaces, while Culex and Aedes lay eggs near water edges or in rafts.
  2. Larva Stage (Wriggler):
    • Duration: 4-14 days, dependent on environmental conditions.
    • Larvae feed on organic matter in water, shedding their skins (molting) four times.
    • Anopheles larvae rest parallel to the water, while Culex and Aedes use siphon tubes to rest at angles.
  3. Pupa Stage (Tumbler):
    • Duration: 1-4 days.
    • The non-feeding stage where adult forms inside. Pupae float and use trumpet-like structures to breathe.
  4. Adult Stage:
    • Duration: 8-34 days.
    • Females require blood meals for egg development, while males feed on nectar.
    • Adults mate within 1-2 days after emerging; females can lay hundreds of eggs over their lifespan.

Why Not Others:

  • 2-3 days: Too short; applies mostly to individual males, not the entire mosquito life cycle.
  • 5-7 days: Covers only part of the life cycle for males or females under harsh conditions.
  • 3-4 months: Longer than typical for mosquito lifespan, as they rarely exceed a month in nature.

Key Takeaway: Mosquitoes typically live 8-34 days, depending on species and environmental factors. The extended life of females, supported by blood meals, enables continuous reproduction in favorable conditions.

questions.text: Flight range for Aedes Mosquito is
questions.solution:
• The flight range of Aedes mosquitoes, particularly Aedes aegypti, is typically around 100 meters from their breeding sites. They prefer to stay close to human dwellings and lay eggs in containers with clean, stagnant water.
  • This limited flight range makes Aedes mosquitoes highly localized vectors, meaning they often transmit diseases like dengue, Zika, and chikungunya within specific areas where they breed.

Comparison of Flight Ranges:

  • Aedes: ~100 meters, preferring to stay near breeding sites and human habitats.
  • Anopheles: Up to 3 km, depending on environmental conditions.
  • Culex: Around 1-2 km but may travel further in search of hosts.
  • Mansonia: Variable, typically less than 1 km, staying near water with vegetation.
  • Comparison of the flight ranges for different mosquito genera:

Key Takeaway: The flight range of Aedes mosquitoes is approximately 100 meters, supporting their localized spread in human-populated areas, which is why effective mosquito control requires reducing breeding sources within close proximity.

questions.text: Aedes mosquito transmit the following diseases except:
questions.solution:
• Aedes mosquitoes are significant vectors for several viral diseases, including:
    • Yellow fever: Transmitted primarily by Aedes aegypti, which breeds in urban areas and is responsible for outbreaks in tropical and subtropical regions.
    • Dengue fever: One of the most widespread mosquito-borne viral infections, with Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus as primary vectors. Dengue has four serotypes and can lead to severe complications like dengue hemorrhagic fever.
    • Chikungunya fever: Caused by the chikungunya virus, it is transmitted by both Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus. Symptoms include high fever and severe joint pain, often debilitating for weeks.
  • Japanese encephalitis (JE) is primarily transmitted by Culex mosquitoes, particularly Culex tritaeniorhynchus, which breed in rice paddies and floodwaters. JE is a significant cause of viral encephalitis in Asia.

Additional Information:

  • Vector Characteristics:
    • Aedes mosquitoes tend to bite during the day, especially early morning and late afternoon, making them particularly important in urban settings.
    • They prefer to breed in clean, stagnant water sources like flower pots, discarded tires, and bird baths.
  • Disease Epidemiology:
    • Dengue fever affects millions annually, particularly in Southeast Asia and Latin America, with climate change affecting mosquito habitats and transmission patterns.
    • Chikungunya outbreaks have been reported globally, often coinciding with periods of high rainfall that create breeding sites.
    • Japanese encephalitis occurs predominantly in rural areas, with vaccination available for high-risk populations.
  • Diseases transmitted by different mosquito genera:

Key Takeaway: Aedes mosquitoes are responsible for the transmission of yellow fever, dengue fever, and chikungunya fever, while Japanese encephalitis is primarily associated with Culex mosquitoes. Understanding the specific vectors for these diseases is crucial for implementing effective control measures and preventing outbreaks.

questions.text: All of the following methods are anti-larval measures except:
questions.solution:
• Anti-larval measures focus on controlling mosquito larvae to prevent their development into adult mosquitoes. Here’s a detailed overview of each method:
    • Intermittent irrigation:
      • Mechanism: By alternating between wet and dry periods, this method disrupts the mosquito breeding cycle.
      • Benefits: Reduces the availability of stagnant water, a critical habitat for mosquito larvae, ultimately leading to a decrease in mosquito populations.
    • Paris green:
      • Mechanism: A toxic chemical traditionally used to kill mosquito larvae in standing water.
      • Usage: Effective in urban environments and agricultural areas where water bodies are present, although it requires careful application due to its toxicity to other aquatic organisms.
    • Gambusia affinis (mosquito fish):
      • Mechanism: These small fish feed on mosquito larvae and can significantly reduce larval populations in water bodies.
      • Advantages: An environmentally friendly biological control method, sustainable, and reduces the reliance on chemical insecticides.
    • Pyrethrum:
      • Function: A natural insecticide effective against adult mosquitoes, derived from the flowers of the chrysanthemum plant.
      • Limitations: While it is useful for adult mosquito control, it does not target larvae and is not effective in reducing larval populations directly.

Additional Anti-Larval Measures:

  • Oil films: Applying a thin layer of oil on water surfaces can suffocate larvae by preventing them from accessing oxygen.
  • Biological control agents: Other predators, such as dragonfly larvae, can also be used to control mosquito larvae populations.
  • Larvicides: Chemical agents specifically formulated to target mosquito larvae without harming other aquatic life (e.g., methoprene, temephos).
  • Various anti-larval measures used for controlling mosquito larvae:

Why Not Others:

  • Intermittent irrigation: Disrupts mosquito breeding sites effectively.
  • Paris green: Specifically targets mosquito larvae in water.
  • Gambusia affinis: Natural predator of mosquito larvae, reducing their numbers efficiently.

Key Takeaway: Pyrethrum is not an anti-larval measure as it primarily targets adult mosquitoes. Methods like intermittent irrigation, Paris green, and Gambusia affinis are essential for controlling mosquito larvae and are integral to integrated pest management strategies, helping to prevent the transmission of diseases such as malaria, dengue, and Zika. Effective larval control is crucial in reducing mosquito populations and mitigating the risk of outbreaks.

questions.text: Which of the following type of mosquitoe can be controlled by removing and destroying the aquatic plants by herbicides?
questions.solution:
• Mansonia mosquitoes have a unique lifecycle that heavily depends on aquatic plants. Here are some key points:
    • Larval Habitat: Mansonia larvae are often associated with aquatic vegetation, as they utilize the roots and leaves for feeding and as resting places.
    • Control Method:
      • Herbicides: By applying herbicides to remove aquatic plants, the available habitat for Mansonia larvae is significantly diminished.
      • Effectiveness: Reducing plant cover directly impacts the larval population, leading to a decrease in adult mosquito emergence.
  • Other Genera:
    • Aedes, Culex, and Anopheles mosquitoes typically thrive in various water bodies but do not rely on aquatic vegetation in the same manner as Mansonia.
    • These mosquitoes may breed in clean water or polluted environments, and controlling their populations generally involves different strategies, such as larvicides or environmental management.

Control Measures for Different Types of Mosquitoes:

  • Aedes:
    • Breeding Sites: Prefer clean, stagnant water (e.g., containers, flower pots).
    • Control Methods: Remove standing water, use larvicides, and apply adulticides for immediate population control.
  • Culex:
    • Breeding Sites: Commonly found in polluted water bodies and sewer systems.
    • Control Methods: Treating polluted water with larvicides, ensuring proper drainage, and employing biological control (e.g., Gambusia affinis).
  • Anopheles:
    • Breeding Sites: Prefer clean water, such as ponds or marshes.
    • Control Methods: Similar to Culex; focus on environmental management, use of larvicides, and biological controls.
  • Control measures for different types of mosquitoes:

Key Takeaway: Mansonia mosquitoes can be effectively controlled by removing aquatic plants using herbicides, as their larvae are closely associated with these plants. In contrast, Aedes, Culex, and Anopheles mosquitoes require different control strategies tailored to their specific breeding habits and environments. Effective mosquito control is essential in preventing the transmission of various mosquito-borne diseases.

questions.text: Lice are not the vectors of:
questions.solution:
• Lice as Vectors: Lice are known vectors for certain diseases, primarily affecting humans. Here's a breakdown of their role:
    • A. Relapsing fever:
      • Vector: Lice (specifically, the body louse, Pediculus humanus corporis).
      • Pathogen: Caused by Borrelia species, transmitted through louse bites and feces.
    • B. Q fever:
      • Not a Vector: Caused by Coxiella burnetii. Transmitted primarily through inhalation of contaminated aerosols or consumption of unpasteurized dairy, not by lice.
    • C. Trench fever:
      • Vector: Lice (particularly body lice).
      • Pathogen: Caused by Bartonella quintana, transmitted through louse bites.
    • D. Epidemic typhus:
      • Vector: Lice (body lice).
      • Pathogen: Caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, transmitted through louse feces when they bite and defecate on the host.

List of Diseases Transmitted by Lice:

  • Epidemic typhus:
    • Transmitted by body lice (Pediculus humanus corporis).
  • Trench fever:
    • Transmitted by body lice.
  • Relapsing fever:
    • Transmitted by body lice (Pediculus humanus corporis).
  • Louse-borne dermatitis:
    • Caused by skin irritation from louse bites.
  • list of diseases transmitted by lice:

Key Takeaway: Q fever is not transmitted by lice, as it is primarily spread through respiratory routes or unpasteurized dairy products. Lice are significant vectors for diseases like epidemic typhus, trench fever, and relapsing fever, highlighting the importance of lice control in preventing these infections.

• Sand fleas are found in India, especially in rural areas.
  • They can burrow into the skin, leading to painful ulcers on the feet.
  • Buboes are linked to lymphatic filariasis and bubonic plague, not sand fleas.
  • Sand fleas are not vectors for Kala-azar; sand flies transmit it.

Overview of Facts about Sand Fleas:

  • Scientific Name: Tunga penetrans
  • Habitat: Common in tropical and subtropical regions, including rural areas of India.
  • Transmission: Burrows into the skin, causing irritation and potential secondary infections.
  • Symptoms:
    • Painful ulcers or lesions, particularly on the feet.
    • Possible secondary infections due to open wounds.
  • So, the correct answer is: (b) Causes ulcers in foot.Overview of facts about sand flies:

Why Not Others:

  • A. Not found in India: Misleading; they are present in rural areas.
  • C. Causes bubo in groin: Not applicable; buboes are linked to other diseases.
  • D. Vector for Kala-azar: Incorrect; sand fleas do not transmit Kala-azar.

Key Takeaway: Sand fleas cause painful ulcers on the feet by burrowing into the skin. They are not vectors for Kala-azar and are found in India, primarily in rural areas. Understanding their characteristics and effects helps in managing and preventing associated health issues.

questions.text: The species of black flies (simulum) are responsible for spread of
questions.solution:
• River blindness (Onchocerciasis):
    • Caused by: The parasitic worm Onchocerca volvulus.
    • Transmission: Black flies (Simulium species) breed near rivers and transmit the parasite through their bites.
    • Symptoms: Severe itching, skin rashes, nodules under the skin, and vision impairment progressing to blindness.
    • Global Impact: Mainly affects sub-Saharan Africa, parts of Latin America, and Yemen, with millions at risk in endemic areas.
    • Control Measures: Includes the use of insecticides in river areas, community treatment programs with ivermectin, and improved water management to reduce black fly populations.

Additional Points on Black Flies and River Blindness:

  • Life Cycle: The parasite develops in the black fly and is transferred to humans during bites. Once in the body, the larvae mature into adult worms that live in subcutaneous tissue.
  • Treatment: Ivermectin effectively kills microfilariae (larval stage) to reduce symptoms and transmission; doxycycline may also target the parasite's endosymbiont bacteria, Wolbachia, reducing fertility in adult worms.
  • Prevention: Widespread distribution of ivermectin in endemic areas and vector control to limit black fly populations.

Why Not Others:

  • B. Sleeping sickness:
    • Caused by Trypanosoma brucei and transmitted by tsetse flies, not black flies.
  • C. Kala Azar:
    • Caused by Leishmania donovani, transmitted by sand flies.
  • D. Oriental sores:
    • Caused by cutaneous forms of Leishmania, transmitted by sand flies.

Key Takeaway: River blindness is a debilitating disease transmitted by black flies, primarily in riverine regions, causing chronic itching and potential blindness if untreated. Community-based ivermectin distribution is crucial for control in endemic regions.

questions.text: Which of the following flies is found in cracks and crevices of walls during daytime:
questions.solution:
• Resting Habitat: Sand flies (Phlebotomine flies) prefer to hide in dark, sheltered areas, such as cracks, crevices of walls, caves, and under vegetation, especially during daylight hours.
  • Behavior: Sand flies are nocturnal feeders, primarily active at dawn and dusk, which helps them avoid predators.
  • Disease Transmission: Sand flies are vectors of diseases like leishmaniasis and sand fly fever, spreading pathogens through bites.
  • Lifecycle: Sand flies lay eggs in moist, sheltered areas and are adapted to environments with organic material like rodent burrows or soil cracks.
  • Vector Control: Indoor residual spraying and insecticide-treated nets help reduce sand fly populations in endemic areas.
  • Preventive Measures: Reducing habitat sources, using repellents, and wearing protective clothing are common strategies to prevent bites.

Overview of the habits of sand flies:

Why Not Others:

  • Housefly:
    • Houseflies (Musca domestica) rest on surfaces exposed to light, including food, garbage, and walls, but they don't prefer dark cracks for resting.
  • Blackfly:
    • Blackflies (Simulium species) breed near fast-moving water and generally rest on vegetation, not cracks or crevices in walls.
  • Tsetse fly:
    • Tsetse flies (Glossina species) rest in shaded vegetation and forested areas, not in indoor or wall crevices.

Key Takeaway: Sand flies are commonly found resting in cracks and crevices during the daytime and are responsible for transmitting leishmaniasis and other diseases in endemic areas.

questions.text: Vector for crimean congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is:
questions.solution:
• Primary Vector: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is primarily spread through ticks, particularly those of the Hyalomma genus.
  • Transmission Mechanism: The disease spreads when an infected tick bites a human or when a person comes into contact with the blood or tissues of infected animals.
  • Epidemiology: CCHF is most common in regions with tick populations, including parts of Africa, Asia, the Middle East, and Eastern Europe.
  • Lifecycle: Hyalomma ticks prefer warm climates and can transmit the virus during various stages of their life cycle.
  • Prevention: Use of insect repellents, protective clothing, and tick control in animal environments can reduce CCHF risk.
  • Human Transmission: Infected individuals can transmit CCHF to others through direct contact with blood or bodily fluids, making healthcare precautions essential.

Key Takeaway: Ticks, especially of the Hyalomma genus, are the primary vectors for Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF), spreading the virus through bites or contact with infected animals.

questions.text: Following are used for treatment of Scabies in India except
questions.solution:
• Crotamiton lotion: Topical treatment for scabies.
  • Sulphur ointment: Older treatment still used in some cases.
  • Ivermectin: Oral medication effective for widespread scabies.
  • Rifampicin: Antibiotic for tuberculosis, not used for scabies.

Additional Points on Scabies Treatment in India:

  • Topical Permethrin is often the first line of treatment for scabies.
  • Dosage of Ivermectin: Typically administered in two doses, one week apart, to ensure eradication.
  • Alternative Options: Benzyl benzoate and lindane lotion are also available but used with caution due to potential side effects.
  • The treatments for scabies commonly used in India:

Why Not Others:

  • A. Crotamiton lotion: Approved and widely used for treating scabies in India.
  • B. Sulphur ointment: An accessible and effective treatment option for scabies, especially in areas with limited resources.
  • C. Ivermectin: Commonly used in cases resistant to topical treatments and effective in mass treatment programs.

Key Takeaway: Rifampicin, an antibiotic, is not used for scabies treatment, whereas Crotamiton, Sulphur ointment, and Ivermectin are effective anti-scabies options commonly used in India.

questions.text: Rat flea transmit following diseases except:
questions.solution:
• Murine typhus:
    • Transmitted by rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) through infected flea feces.
  • Pneumonic plague:
    • Can be transmitted by rat fleas that feed on infected rats and bite humans.
  • Chiggerosis:
    • Caused by chigger mites, not fleas; therefore, not transmitted by rat fleas.
  • Hymenolepis diminuta:
    • A tapeworm that can be transmitted through fleas, including rat fleas.

Diseases Transmitted by Rat Fleas:

  • Murine typhus (Rickettsia typhi)
  • Bubonic and pneumonic plague (Yersinia pestis)
  • Hymenolepis diminuta infection, a zoonotic parasitic disease
  • Diseases transmitted by rat fleas:

Why Not Others:

  • A. Murine typhus: Commonly spread by rat fleas and recognized as a flea-borne typhus.
  • B. Pneumonic plague: Known for flea transmission during plague outbreaks.
  • D. Hymenolepis diminuta: Rat fleas play a role in its transmission cycle.

Key Takeaway: Rat fleas are vectors for murine typhus, plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta, but they do not transmit chiggerosis, which is caused by chigger mites.

• Cyclodevelopmental stage: Refers to a stage in the life cycle of certain parasites where they undergo developmental changes within the vector without a change in form.
  • Filaria:
    • Wuchereria bancrofti and other filarial worms (e.g., Brugia malayi) undergo cyclodevelopmental transmission.
    • The microfilariae are released into the blood, which are ingested by the mosquito during a blood meal.
    • Inside the mosquito, they develop into infective larvae that can be transmitted to a new host when the mosquito bites again.

Additional Points:

  • Infective Stages: The development of larvae inside the mosquito typically takes about 7-14 days, during which environmental factors like temperature and humidity can influence the maturation rate.
  • Vectors: Common vectors for filarial infections include Culex, Aedes, and Anopheles mosquitoes, making them critical in the transmission cycle.
  • Disease Impact: Filarial infections can lead to significant health issues, such as lymphatic filariasis, which causes lymphedema and elephantiasis.

Why Not Others:

  • A. Malaria:
    • Features both asexual (in humans) and sexual reproduction (in mosquitoes).
    • The lifecycle includes gametocyte formation in humans and sporogonic development in mosquitoes, classifying it as cyclopropagative.
  • C. Plague:
    • Transmitted via flea bites, primarily involving mechanical transmission of the bacteria Yersinia pestis without a developmental stage.
  • D. Cholera:
    • Caused by ingestion of contaminated food or water and does not involve any vector or developmental stages within organisms.

Key Takeaway: Filarial infections exemplify cyclodevelopmental transmission, where larvae mature within the mosquito, emphasizing the need for effective vector control to reduce transmission risks.

questions.text: Which of the following is 'nuisance mosquito'?
questions.solution:
• Culex mosquitoes:
    • Often referred to as "nuisance mosquitoes" due to their biting behavior, which can be bothersome to humans.
    • They tend to bite at dusk and during the night, making their presence felt without being aggressive.
  • Comparison with Other Genera:
    • Aedes: Known for their aggressive biting and transmission of diseases like dengue and Zika, making them more than just a nuisance.
    • Anopheles: Primarily known for transmitting malaria, hence significant in public health.
    • Mansonoides: Less commonly encountered, and primarily linked to the transmission of certain filarial infections, not classified mainly as nuisances.

Why Not Others:

  • A. Anopheles:
    • Recognized as disease vectors, particularly for malaria, and not categorized as nuisance mosquitoes.
  • C. Aedes:
    • Known for aggressive biting behavior and vectoring several viral diseases; hence, they are more than mere nuisances.
  • D. Mansonoides:
    • Associated with certain diseases but not as prevalent as Culex in terms of nuisance complaints.

Key Takeaway: Culex mosquitoes are classified as nuisance mosquitoes due to their bothersome presence without being major vectors of severe diseases, unlike Aedes or Anopheles.
